SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe prime minister said her commitment to avoiding a hard border was ‘unshakeable’Click to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May’s attempts to end the Brexit impasse have been dismissed as the “same old rhetoric” by Northern Ireland political leaders following last-ditch talks to salvage her deal.The prime minister held&nbspmeetings at Stormont&nbspon Wednesday, where she sought to convince the five main parties of her commitment to avoiding a hard border in&nbspIreland.But she faced accusations she’d turned up “empty-handed with the same old rhetoric, with no plan, no credibility and frankly no honour” and her attempts to find an alternative to the unpopular backstop mechanism were described as “chasing unicorns”.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialDUP leader Arlene Foster also ramped up the pressure on Ms May to strip the backstop from the deal, saying&nbspMPs had given the prime minister a mandate to “replace” the insurance policy.It comes as European Council president Donald Tusk drew fury from Eurosceptics by saying there was a “special place in hell” for Brexiteers without a plan.Created with Sketch. A police officer speaks with anti-Brexit protester Steve BrayPolice surround a pro-Brexit protester after he confronted a pro-European protester Conservative MP David Davies, wearing a gopro camera, speaks to anti-Brexit protester Steve BrayOn a two-day visit to Belfast, Ms May set herself at odds with Brexit hardliners by saying she was seeking “changes” to the controversial backstop, rather than its total removal from the withdrawal agreement.The backstop&nbspwould see the UK tied to a customs union – and Northern Ireland&nbspbound to some single market&nbsprules – if a trade deal cannot be agreed.The DUP and Ulster Unionists are vociferously opposed to the mechanism but Sinn Fein, the SDLP and the Alliance Party argue it&nbspis the only way to maintain a frictionless border&nbsppost-Brexit.Ms Foster told reporters at Stormont there had been a “useful engagement” with the prime minister where the party reminded Ms May of their opposition to the Irish backstop, as the DUP believe it creates ergence between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.She said: “We reiterated again the fact that the backstop was the problem in relation to the withdrawal agreement and the Brady amendment that was put down in the House of Commons last week gives her the mandate now to go to Brussels as she intends to&nbspon Thursday and we look forward to hearing the outcome of that.“As I’ve said, the Brady amendment is clear in relation to the withdrawal agreement that the backstop needs to be replaced. That is her mandate and that’s what I expect her to take to Brussels.”Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald warned the prime minister that she risked breaking up the UK if she engaged in brinkmanship with the EU.She said: “We have told her that the British strategy of running down the clock and playing a game of chicken with Ireland and Irish interests is profoundly unacceptable and wrong.“We have told her that the days of Britain dictating to Ireland or Irish people, that those days are over and will not return.”She accused Ms May of acting in “absolute bad faith”, adding:&nbsp“If British politicians cannot accept the specific needs of this country, of the Northern Irish, if British politics is incapable of acknowledging and upholding the Good Friday Agreement and the hardening of the border, then the only last option – the backstop of last resort – is a referendum on Irish unity.”Naomi Long, leader of the Alliance Party of Northern Ireland, said&nbspthe prime minister&nbspgave no detail about what the “alternative arrangements” could be to replace the backstop in their meeting.‘We’re totally in the dark’ – Belfast locals on BrexitShe went on: “I am tired of people chasing unicorns. It has to stop, we don’t have time.“We need practical solutions that are going to actually address the realities that we are facing.”UUP leader Robin Swann said if Ms May cannot negotiate an extension and no deal is reached, then she must introduce direct rule for Northern Ireland.And SDLP leader Colum Eastwood said that his party had told Ms May that it is now time to “put up or shut up”, as the backstop was only viable solution to the border issue.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. also calls&nbspfor 28-day time limit to end ‘trauma’&nbspof indefinite detentionClick to followIndy PoliticsThe Joint Committee on Human Rights said the current system should be ‘urgently’ reformed to make it more fair and humaneThe Home Office should lose the power to detain people in immigration detention centres, MPs have said in a report which also calls for an end to locking people up indefinitely.The Joint Committee on Human Rights (JCHR) said the current system should be “urgently” reformed to make it more fair and&nbsphumane, and urged&nbspthat more should to be done to make detention estates “less like prisons”.It also called for a 28-day time limit to end the “trauma” of indefinite detention, recommending that only in exceptional circumstances should the Home Office be able to apply to a judge who would decide whether a further period of detention should be authorised.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialCalls to end indefinite detention in the UK were recently backed by the UN refugee agency, and home secretary Sajid Javid last year pledged to look into how time limits on the detention of immigrants work in other countries.The committee said that under the current immigration detention system, “mistakes were inevitable” because there was “no independence in the decision making” as the power to detain is wielded by the department which is charged with deportations and removals.Citing the series of mistakes accepted by the Home Office in detention cases involving Commonwealth members of the Windrush generation, the report notes a “lack of rigour” in detention decisions. But the decision set off a nightmare that saw him lose his job, detained twice and almost deported to Jamaica. Jamaica-born Anthony Bryan poses outside his home in Edmonton, north London. Now 60 and a grandfather, Bryan thought the issue could be resolved swiftly, as he legally moved to Britain with his family as part of the Windrush generation of Caribbean migrants after World War II. In 1948, the ship Windrush brought the first group of migrants from the West Indies to help rebuild post-war Britain, and many others followed from around the Commonwealth. A 1971 law gave them indefinite leave to remain, but many never formalised their status, often because they were children who came over on their parents' passports and then never applied for their own. But the decision set off a nightmare that saw him lose his job, detained twice and almost deported to Jamaica. Jamaica-born Anthony Bryan poses outside his home in Edmonton, north London. Now 60 and a grandfather, Bryan thought the issue could be resolved swiftly, as he legally moved to Britain with his family as part of the Windrush generation of Caribbean migrants after World War II. In 1948, the ship Windrush brought the first group of migrants from the West Indies to help rebuild post-war Britain, and many others followed from around the Commonwealth. A 1971 law gave them indefinite leave to remain, but many never formalised their status, often because they were children who came over on their parents' passports and then never applied for their own. Three Jamaican immigrants (left to right) John Hazel, a 21-year-old boxer, Harold Wilmot, 32, and John Richards, a 22-year-old carpenter, arriving at Tilbury on board the ex-troopship 'Empire Windrush', smartly dressed in zoot suits and trilby hats.Newly arrived Jamaican immigrants on board the 'Empire Windrush' at Tilbury in 1948.It said that in cases where the Home Office plans to detain a person – which applied to 45 per cent of cases – it should ask an independent body for authority to make a detention order.Descirbing the process, chair of the committee&nbspHarriet Harman&nbspsaid:&nbsp“A civil servant – nameless, faceless and behind closed doors – just ticks a box to detain them. The first that person will know about it is when someone bangs on their door in the early hours of the morning to bundle them into an immigration enforcement van and take them to a detention centre.Algerian man dies in London immigration detention centreGovernment plans risk ‘riding roughshod’ over rights of immigrantsSuicides in immigration removal centres kept ‘state secret’, MPs told“Those we get to hear about are probably only the tip of the iceberg, but we do know that £21m was paid out by the Home Office in just five years to compensate for wrongful detention, and terrible mistakes are certainly what happened in the Windrush cases.”The committee said it had looked at the Home Office files of Windrush citizens who had been unable to prove their UK residence, and that there was “masses” of evidence, including records of national insurance contributions going back decades.“If there had been any independence in the decision making, these people would never have been detained, yet they were detained not once but twice. The papers in their files were ignored, and the pleas of their families were swept aside,” Ms Harman added.“After the right to life, the right not to be unlawfully detained is one of the most important human rights. It should not be the case that a person has fewer protections from wrongful detention as an immigrant than they would if they had actually committed a crime.”The MPs also said detainees should have better and more consistent access to legal aid to challenge their detention, and that a reinstatement of legal aid for immigration cases should be considered.UN backs calls for time limit on UK immigration detentionSam Grant, policy and campaigns manager for Liberty, supported the calls, describing indefinite detention as an “ineffective and inefficient waste of money and human life”.&nbspBella Sankey, director of Detention Action, also backed the calls, saying&nbspa 28-day time limit was “urgently” needed along with early judicial oversight and safeguards against “cat and mouse” re-detentions.“The JCHR has expertly laid bare the injustice and abuse inherent in our current system. Parliament will have the opportunity to take this historic step when it considers the immigration bill and we urge MPs of all parties to take it,” she added.Leila Zadeh, executive director of UK Lesbian &amp Gay Immigration Group, welcomed the report but called for the government to bring an end to the detention of LGBT+ people, saying it was “wholly inappropriate”“They run a significant risk of being locked up among other people who may display the same discriminatory attitudes and hostility from which they have fled. They also frequently struggle to be granted refugee status if they have to make their asylum applications from inside a detention centre,” she added.The Home Office has been approached for comment.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereAsylum and ImmigrationOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. You put it under the cold tap, get all the gross stuff off, smoosh it around a bit and separate the bones, feathers, seaweed and other stuff, explained NIWA volunteer Jodie Warren.It was while undergoing this sorting process that the team found something large and hard.&nbspCreated with Sketch.'Children and animals' photo contest Show all 18Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The stick was in good condition, considering where it had come from, and after leaving the stick to dry out for a few weeks, the team discovered files which may help to find the owner.Researchers said there was a more serious side to the discovery, however.It is very worrying that these amazing Antarctic animals have plastic like this inside them, Ms Warren said.The USB contained photos of sealions&nbspand a video of a mother sealion and her baby frolicking in shallow waters.The only clue to who might have taken them is the nose of a blue kayak, NIWA said, adding that the return of the USB stick comes with a price.The leopard seal researchers would like some more leopard seal scat please.Leopard seals are the second biggest seal species in the Antarctic, after the elephant seal, known for their spotted fur.Growing up to 11 feet with inch-long canine teeth, the leopard seal's only natural predator is thought to be the killer whale.Additional reporting from agencies&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. In his first interview since announcing his run for prime minister, he cited the dismantling of settlements in Gaza in 2005 as an example that could be replicated in the West Bank.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trial“All sides had a lot at stake and the state managed to do it without tearing the country apart. It was done legally, carried out by the State of Israel and the IDF, and even though it was very painful for the settlers, it was handled well,” he said.“We must take the lessons of the disengagement and implement them in other arenas.”Many Israelis consider the Gaza disengagement under then prime minister Ariel Sharon a historic mistake that emboldened the Islamist group Hamas.Created with Sketch.Palestinians await Israeli demolition of their homes in the West Bank  Show all 7Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Children play as their parents prepare for their homes to be destroyed (Bel Trew)A toddler plays in the dirt of Khan al-Ahmar village (Bel Trew)Palestinian flags festoon the Bedouin village of Khan al-Ahmar as they await eviction (Bel Trew)Children play as their parents brace themselves for the bulldozers (Bel Trew)Iman, 7, says she does not want to leave her home (Bel Trew)The demolition order includes the village’s school, which provides education for some 170 children from five different Bedouin communities.&nbsp(Bel Trew)The playground of the school which will likely be demolished in the coming days (Bel Trew)Children play as their parents prepare for their homes to be destroyed (Bel Trew)A toddler plays in the dirt of Khan al-Ahmar village (Bel Trew)Palestinian flags festoon the Bedouin village of Khan al-Ahmar as they await eviction (Bel Trew)Children play as their parents brace themselves for the bulldozers (Bel Trew)Iman, 7, says she does not want to leave her home (Bel Trew)The demolition order includes the village’s school, which provides education for some 170 children from five different Bedouin communities.&nbsp(Bel Trew)The playground of the school which will likely be demolished in the coming days (Bel Trew)But the continued growth of settlements in the West Bank is seen as one of the greatest barriers to an eventual peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians. More than 400,000 Israelis live in the territory, and a further 200,000 in East Jerusalem, both of which were captured by Israel in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.Most of the international community views settlements as illegal – in 2016 the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution that described them as a “flagrant violation” of international law. Palestinians argue they harm the chances of a two-state solution by taking land that would eventually make up a Palestinian state.Settlement construction has surged under Donald Trump, who has taken a more relaxed approach to the issue than previous presidents. Data compiled by Peace Now, an advocacy group in Israel, found that construction had risen 20 per cent in the first nine months of 2018, compared with the year before.Speaking on Tuesday, the UN secretary general&nbspAntonio Guterres&nbspdescribed settlements as “a major obstacle to peace”, which should be “halted and reversed”.“Ongoing settlement construction and expansion in the occupied West Bank, including East Jerusalem, is illegal under United Nations resolutions and international law,” he said. “A two-state solution is the only way to achieve the inalienable rights of the Palestinian people and secure a sustainable solution to the conflict.”According to current polling, Mr Gantz is expected to win about 24 seats in the Knesset, trailing Mr Netanyahu’s Likud&nbspby six seats.The former general,&nbspfrequently described as “charismatic” in profiles,&nbspwas the Israeli army’s chief of staff during the 2014 Gaza war, codenamed Operation Protective Edge. Mr Gantz has highlighted his role in the war in promotional material for his campaign.Israel launched the military operation in the Gaza Strip following the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers by Hamas members. The subsequent war left more than 2,200 Palestinians dead.“Sixty-three per cent, or 1,391, did not take part in the fighting, including 526 minors,” according to Israeli human rights group B’Tselem. “It is estimated that 18,000 homes were destroyed or severely damaged and that more than 100,000 Palestinians were rendered homeless.” &nbspOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: jacob rees mogg brexit compromise
story: It would mean extending the transition period from the end of  to December  but with the UK following EU rules and paying an extra £billion into Brussels coffers.It would also mean replacing the Irish backstop with technological solutions while leaving the option open of exiting the EU on World Trade Organisation rules –a free-trade deal has not been struck.The idea was named after housing minister Kit Malthouse, who brought the two sides together in secret. Here, leading Conservative Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg offers his view:THE EU has taken an almost religious approach to Britain’s latest move towards securing a Brexit deal.The compromise put forward by my fellow MP Kit Malthouse has been immediately dismissed and any prospect of further negotiation turned away. The mighty EU has spoken and will not be gainsaid.In negotiating the compromise, both Leavers and Remainers made concessions. This has led to criticism from their supporters, as I found in my weekly radio show on LBC.Callers felt that I had become a “snowflake” in my willingness to see £billion of taxpayers’ money spent without giving us any advantage in future negotiations.The legal basis for the EU demanding money is weak. A House of Lords report came to the conclusion that while there could be a moral obligation, under UK, EU and international law there was no valid or forceful claim.The only motive for paying is to secure a good future deal, rather than to pay a ransom for our freedom.Yet I have come to the conclusion that leaving on March  is at risk and exiting the EU is a prize worth paying for and on which thewill be great.Unfortunately, in spite of the Referendum result, the majority of MPs are reluctant to see the UK part from the EU and at the least want terms that mirror our membership.This may well not be the view of most voters, who seem to welcome the clean break and are not fearful of the scare stories.It is, therefore, crucial to ensure the fears of those who are far from enthusiastic Brexiteers are assuaged. This is where the Malthouse Compromise comes in.By offering money and making the prospect of a No Deal Brexit unlikely, possible moderate former Remainers are willing to avoid Parliamentary tactics that would frustrate our departure.They can accept the replacement of the backstop, which could keep us tied in to the EU’s rules and courts forever, with a routine trade agreement based on existing processes commonly used around the world.This would not hamper the development of a future relationship which would be discussed once we have left. Although in these discussions we would lose the leverage of cash, we would not be squeezed by the backstop.The second stage of the compromise is that the implementation period could be extended by one year. Currently the withdrawal agreement proposes a maximum of two years.In this time we would remain subject to EU laws and what follows, but it makes the prospect of not finalising a future relationship less likely, which gives comfort to those who are determined to avoid No Deal.In my view, an extra  months of vassalage after  years is an unwelcome but not unaffordable price to pay. title: theresa may brexit negotiations poker
story: Last week’s Commons victory over Remainers — a surprise to everyone including the PM herself — has given her a strong hand to play for Britain.The PM has the unexpected authority of Parliament to scrub the hated Northern Ireland backstop. Her squabbling party has called a temporary truce. And nobody, including the EU, wants Jeremy Corbyn to take control.Even Labour MPs are rallying behind her — at a price. And working-class voters have given the Tories a healthy seven-point lead. They might even win a snap election.Played skilfully, this could win a deal that satisfies both Remainers and Leavers.Yet there are fears Mrs May will use it to revive her wretched Chequers plan, which sparked the resignations of Boris Johnson and David Davis, or the botched deal thrown out last month by a -vote margin.She has made a worrying start by apparently binning the No Deal card — the only one that truly scares the EU. Mrs May has no intention of playing this ace — and never had.There are other worrying signs.This showdown with EU hardliners requires fresh thinking and shrewd advice from seasoned players. Crawford Falconer, an ex-World Trade Organisation ambassador, was recruited by the Brexit department for precisely these skills.Indeed, he is the ONLY person in the Government machine who has ever negotiated a trade deal.Yet bafflingly, Mrs May is keeping this star player on the sidelines.Instead, she will fly to Brussels with Whitehall mandarin Olly Robbins, the pro-EU fanatic who plunged Britain into the backstop trap she is now under pressure to escape from.Robbins hates Brexit and has privately warned the PM this is Mission Impossible.Mrs May — herself a Remainer who has never grasped the case for Brexit — will be joined by trusted “deputy PM” David Lidington, a dyed-in-the-wool Brussels worshipper.In such company, even the inclusion in her team of a thundering Brexiteer Attorney-General Geoffrey Cox is only mildly reassuring.Mrs May is notoriously stubborn. She can also be devious.After nearly three years, even her closest political colleagues — who can be counted on one hand with a couple of missing digits — have no idea what her Brexit might look like.Voters are increasingly irritated by this foot-dragging.Why should we remain part of an organisation that wants to punish us by stealing Gibraltar, Northern Ireland and our car industry Nobody who watched the brutal humiliation of poor little Greece will be surprised. This tragic and insolvent nation should never have been admitted to the EU, still less the Eurozone.Only with the assistance of US banking giant Goldman Sachs — “The Vampire Squid” — got them in under the wire. Once inside, they launched a borrowing and spending binge which ended in tears in the  crash.Greece might have flourished as a cheap but lovely tourist economy. Instead, it is now being cruelly tormented by Brussels and lumbered with multi-billion euros debts it can never repay.Greece symbolises all that is wrong with arrogant Brussels — the catastrophic Euro, inflexible economic policies and mass unemployment for under-s.Above all, there is the sneering contempt of unsackable Eurocrats for the million people they rule from subsidised ivory towers.Theresa May is a poor negotiator who never truly believed No Deal is better than a bad deal.Without this implicit threat, Brussels will give little and demand much in . It would be a pleasure to eat my words and watch Mrs May play a blinder.She can use her good luck to land a historic victory. story: The Government’s medical advisors suggest leaving phones outside the bedroom at night to ensure a good quality sleep.And they recommend taking a break from screen-based activities, such as TV sites.Prof Dame Sally Davies, Chief Medical Officer for England, said: “Time spent online can be of great benefit to children and young people, providing opportunities for learning and skills development, as well as allowing young people to find support and information.“But we need to take a precautionary approach and our advice will support children to reap these benefits and protect them from harm.“Technology is an unavoidable aspect of modern le and technology companies have a duty of care.“They must make more effort to keep their users safe from harm, particularly children and young people.”Other guidelines say mums and dads should tell kids to put their screens away when crossing the road or doing an activity that needs their full attention.And they should set a good example by story: Kenneth Moyer Jr, , is looking for ,or more in damages from the popular fast food chain.He says he drank most of the shake before realised the rodent was inside his cup.The construction worker bought the drink when he went through the McDonald’s drive-thru in Akron at around .pm on December  and bought another chocolate milkshake for his friend.He started sipping his shake as he drove his friend home and said he noticed the straw kept getting clogged up.Moyer told the Akron Beacon Journal: “I got irritated with the straw.“I really wasn’t thinking about it.”He says he drove home after dropping off his friend and left his milkshake in his truck and came back a few minutes later to get his cigarettes and he then saw the straw start to move.When Moyer lted the lid, which had only about a quarter of the drink left, he saw the live mouse.He then called his girlfriend to come and have a look.Moyer claims he fell ill later that day and was vomiting.The man ed to the same branch of McDonald’s at around .pm the same day and explained to the manager what had happened.Reports say the manager accused him of putting the mouse in the cup himself.He phoned the company’s headquarters the next day and was offered gt cards or the opportunity to make an insurance claim.Moyer chose to make a claim.He told the paper: “The bottom line is its nasty and its wrong.“However it got in there, it was wrong.”Moyer later froze the cup and the mouse and his lawyer then sent them off to be tested.The franchise co-owner is contesting the claims saying they are “wildly fabricated and .”Christina Joliat, Moyer’s current lawyer, says McDonald’s have been able to contest the claims because Moyer at first “mistakenly” said that he had left the cup unattended for an hour.She says Moyer later realised the cup had only been out of sight for about “ten minutes at most”.Now Moyer is taking legal action with Joliat wanting the test results from the cup and mouse as well as seeing surveillance footage from McDonald’s.She said: “We want the video. We want to see what happened.“That will clear everything up.”Carl Blickle, co-owner of Rubber City Arches, said: “Although we do not typically comment about pending litigation, we can confidently and adamantly state that the implications made in the complaint are wildly fabricated and .“We have served the Akron area for over  years, have made safety and cleanliness top priorities and remain proud of our track record. We eagerly await our opportunity to share the facts in court.”McDonalds has been contacted for comment.

title: donald tusk brexit sun says opinion
story: Yet with one jaw-droppingly crass ­diatribe about Brexit campaigners he has further poisoned the negotiating well and converted hordes of aghast Remainers to Leave’s cause.What possessed him  What did he hope to gain from such a tantrum Did he think Boris Johnson and others alone would feel chastened That .million Leave voters wouldn’t feel they too were being abused  It couldn’t be clearer what disdain Tusk and his arrogant acolytes also have for them.The Sun doesn’t believe in hell, or a “special place” roped off there awaiting leading Brexiteers.Butwe wanted to match Tusk’s juvenile rhetoric, we might speculate that Satan’s flames are more likely to consume an unaccountable elite whose ideology condemned millions across the continent to long-term unemployment.Who have such disregard for democracy that they have tried endlessly to bully its oldest champions into reversing our biggest ever ballot box mandate.Who are so desperate to hobble Britain that they seek to impose exit terms so vengeful and harsh they would tear our United Kingdom apart.It’s no surprise to see diehard Remainers like Anna Soubry spinning for Tusk.More moderate ones now see that these sneering, sniggering goons are exactly why we voted as we did on June , .WE have no sympathy for the reckless rich kids who broke into Stansted to ground a plane deporting failed asylum seekers.It is disgraceful not one will serve jail time, given the gravity of the offence and widespread chaos they caused.A little “unpaid work” is no deterrent. It’s a green light for others. Yet these entitled hand-wringers still have the gall to whine about being inconvenienced.Tough. They should thank their lucky stars they are impeccably middle-class.Anyone  caught breaking into an international airport with bolt cutters and causing mayhem would be in a cell.VIKKI Orvice was brilliant and brave.But her legacy isn’t just the exclusives she broke or the insight she shared in her long Sun career. It lies in the rapidly rising number of talented women now reporting on and analysing sport in newspapers and on TV and radio.Vikki began as a Sun football writer back in . It is hard now to imagine quite how unusual that was — and that is a tribute to the trail she blazed.Like many in sport, we will miss her humour, professionalism and kindness.We are proud she was one of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russian nerve agent suspect could be in uk
story: A military intelligence officer using the likely fake name of Sergey Fedotov was booked on the same flights to and from Britain used by the two known would-be assassins.But he suddenly checked himself and his baggage off the Moscow-bound plane shortly before departure, and it’s not known when – or– he left the country.One possibility is that Fedotov, whose passport said he was , remained in the UK after discovering Sergei Skripal, , and daughter Yulia, , had survived the attack.A source told The : “It is not clear why Fedotov did not board the flight.But at the last minute he checked himself and his bags off it.He could still have been running around Britain.”Fedotov’s fake passport number was only a few digits dferent from the ones used by Russian intelligence agents Alexander Mishkin and Anatoliy Chepiga – who were also travelling under  names.The senior GRU agents had been awarded Russias highest honour for services in Ukraine.They were captured on CCTV stalking the streets of Salisbury on the day of the attempted hit - but there are no known images of Fedotov.His true identity has not yet been discovered, and it’s not clear what role he played in the attempted hit of Sergei Skripal – a former GRU intelligence officer who betrayed the Kremlin by selling secrets to MI.Some experts believe Fedotov could have brought the Novichok nerve agent into the UK.Or he may have carried out secret reconnaissance to let the others know of Skripals’ movements.The revelation Fedotov was supposed to be on the same March  flight as the other two Russian agents was broken by respected Russian news website Fontanka.Fedotov previously travelled to the UK in March  and March  and again in , according to the site.Although the Skripals miraculously survived the nerve agent poisoning, they’re likely to have been left with health problems as a result.And Brit Dawn Sturgess died after inadvertently spraying herself with the substance, which had been disguised in a perfume bottle and discarded by the hitmen.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may unity plan scrap brexit deal
story: The PM faces a barrage of abuse from Brussels bosses when she flies to Europe’s capital in a bid to renegotiate her EU exit deal.But ministers close to No told The Sun that she secretly wants the EU’s help to abandon the new plan, dubbed the Malthouse Compromise.Drawn up by senior Tory Leavers and Remainers, it replaces the unpopular Irish backstop with a new system of stand-off customs checks.Allies say Mrs May knows EU leaders will never accept the ambitious new plan with just  days to go until the UK leaves, and wants to swtly move on over the weekend to pressing for legally binding changes to toughen up the current backstop.One Leave-backing minister said: “The PM needs Brussels to kill off Malthouse quickly.“She can’t do it herself, she knows the EU has to do it for her or the ERG will never forgive her.“But until that happens, she won’t be able to do the new deal that the members states want to do too now.”Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay is also said to agree with the PM’s assessment.The Cabinet minister is using intensive talks this week with the Malthouse Compromise group of senior backbench Tories to “pick apart” their plan.EU Commission boss Jean-Claude Juncker slammed the Malthouse Compromise plan after talks with Irish premier Leo Varadkar on Wednesday.Mr Juncker said: “Alternative arrangements are for the future, not for now. When it comes to the future relations, we can have a look into alternative arrangements. But they can never replace the backstop.“We are sticking to the line that we set on Day One.”But Mr Varadkar held out hope for other changes when he revealed he had invited Mrs May to Dublin for Brexit talks over dinner on Friday evening.No last night played down the prospect of getting a breakthrough in time to put to MPs in next Thursday’s Commons votes.A senior Downing Street source said: “If the clouds clear then great, but realistically it’s not where we’re going.”The source added that the Government would have to put “something” down to vote on next Thursday but said he expects the “focus” will be on other amendments such as attempts to legislate against a no deal Brexit.Abandoning the new plan to instead fight for a time limit or exit mechanism to the current backstop instead risks infuriating arch Tory Eurosceptic Jacob Rees-Mogg’s European Research Group of hardline MPs.They insisted on Wednesday that the PM must demand the EU accept the unity plan or face a new Commons defeat next week.There is “a very slim chance” of Mrs May winning the next crucial Commons vote on February she doesn’t, a senior ERG figure said.But government whips now think they could whittle down the ERG’s rebellion to around  diehardsthe PM does win other legally binding changes.And up to  Labour MPs will back the PM’s Brexit dealshe allows Parliament a say in trade talks – ex-Shadow Minister Lisa Nandy declared yesterday.She said a commitment that Parliament could help “frame” Britain’s post Brexit direction after March  could be enough to get a huge number of opposition MPs over the title: mps go home early crucial brexit laws
story: Politicians sloped off at .pm - more than four hours earlier than usual for a Wednesday.This is despite a backlog of six draft Brexit laws still needing to pass through Parliament and hundreds of Statutory Instruments - secondary legislation that transfer EU powers back to the UK Government.Last week the Government cancelled MPs’ week-long February holiday in order to make more time to pass crucial Brexit laws.And a string of ministers have warned that Brexit Day is likely to have to be pushed back to make more time to pass necessary laws.But this week the Government has announced just a skeleton programme with uncertainty surrounding the plans for Brexit legislation.But No defended the early finish. The Prime Minister’s spokesman said MPs had been asked to sit beyond midnight on several occasions recently.Labour’s Diana Johnson said the situation was “bang out of order”, writing on Twitter: “Considering Brexit is just  days away this is totally irresponsible!”SNP chief whip Patrick Gray said: “Seemingly the Tory Government thinks there’s nothing worth debating or discussing.”Labour MP Verendra Sharma from the anti-Brexit group Best for Britain stormed: “This is not on. Parliament still has tons of legislation to get through before the end of March, including thousands of pages of statutory instruments.“Brexit is the most important legislative and political process since the Second World War. It makes no sense to go home and avoid working on ensuring the country’s future when there’s so little time left.”With  days to go, the Government is running out of time to pass the necessary legislation needed to implement Brexit. The PM first needs to win a Commons majority for a deal - in a so-called Meaningful Vote.Then the Government needs to pass the European Union Withdrawal Agreement Bill that will bring the Brexit deal into law. This needs to pass the Commons and the Lords before exit day - currently March .Several other bills covering agriculture, healthcare, fisheries and trade also need to pass through Parliament.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . All two-and-a-half yapping hours of it, on ITV, with a bad hangover, in the company of presenters Ben Fogle and Sara Cox.A test beyond personal endurance not because of the alcohol or dogs, who are a largely blameless lot, but the presence of their barmy owners, who attribute all sorts of superpowers to their dumb little mutts and blur the human animal relationship way beyond the point of reason and sometimes even good taste.Hits Radio DJ Gemma Atkinson, for instance, claimed: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without Norman”, her pet sproodle.Which is a hell of a guilt trip to pin on any dog.While Spandau Ballet’s Martin Kemp was seen, sitting alongside Popsie the poodle and his Wham! backing-singer we Shirlie, exclaiming: “I’ll say this for her,she does do a poo she goes into the spare bathroom.”The least you’d expect, frankly, after  years of marriage.The case study that really finished me off, though, was a dog dancing instructor called Joan Clark and her powder puff hounds, whose act, as described by Sara Cox, was: “All building up to the big finish. Can she pull it off  Joan points to the spot and it’s one, two, three pups between her legs.”CHANNEL ’s Pure is a comedy drama about a woman who suffers from the sixth sense of seeing naked people and is so tormented by her condition she screams: “F***ing stop. Make it stop.”So she can read minds as well.QUIZ show doughballs of the week. The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Real Madrid play their home football matches in which Spanish city ”John: “Barcelona.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman Emperor Augustus ”Jorge: “July.”Ben Shephard: “Hajduk Split are a football team from which eastern European country ”Jenner: “Japan.”And Joe Lycett: “In his song Le On Mars, David Bowie wonderedthere was le on which planet ”Amber: “Jupiter.” Andy Murray texting Good Morning Britain with the :am request: “Please stop discussing my genitals on national television.”Andrew Neil ripping all of Ken Livingstone’s socialist fantasies about Venezuela into tiny shreds, on This Week.And The Time It Takes answer contestant John gave to the question: “The metaphorical breaking of which body part brings good luck to an actor ” “Neck.” A thought that’s occurred to me every time I watch the Baftas.FAIR play, I thought, to Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair. They really seemed to have all the important ITV advertising bases covered.First thing in the morning they’re dropping regular hints about “bothersome vaginas” during Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain sht. Then there they were again, on Sunday night, directly before Gemma Collins skated at Dancing On Ice.Although, I say “skated,” you’d see marginally more movement from the Larsen C ice shelf in Antarctica than we got from Gemma on this week’s show.The heroic Matt Evers had to shove, heave, prod and generally wield her like a hypermarket shopping trolley, in fact, just to get Gemma turning on her axis.One very calculated burst of tears later, though, the mug punters had voted her through for yet another week and she’d parked her over-entitled backside on Piers Morgan’s sofa early yesterday morning.So where the hell was Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair when the occasion really called for them Asleep on the job, that’s where. Call yourself a “relief” GREAT Sporting Insights. Martin Keown: “Abramovich has spent £.billion at Cha. That’s £million per championship.”Jermaine Jenas: “The ball misses Trippier’s head by a second.”John Inverdale: “Warren Gatland began his reign  years ago to the day, tomorrow.”And Paul Merson: “Petr Cech was a great shop spotter.”Sent in by Tom Baxter, Denny, Stirlingshire. Picture research Jimbo.RANDOM TV irritations: The widespread but mistaken belief that “you just can’t have too much Romesh Ranganathan”.The Voice UK audience member who shouted: “Olly, I think you should sing.” Jonathan Davies’ complete inability to keep his Welsh bias out of the rugby commentary box.ITV’s Small Fortune already looking like the worst game show of the year.  And catchphrase-chasing hosts Alesha Dixon and Jordan Banjo declaring, “Things are getting really seri-arse”, on The Greatest Dancer, just at the point things were getting even more tedi-arse.TV OBSERVATION round. Who said the following last week “It looks like it’s dragging its legs on the floor, doing a hip wiggle. But it’s actually scent-marking with its anal glands, on the side of a track, on the side of a road, anywhere a passing male might snf it.”A Iolo Williams on Winterwatch’s pine marten B Sam Matterface on Dancing On Ice’s Gemma Collins Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa bid mend uks ties
story: NewsTheresa May in bid to mend UKs ties with Brussels after Tusks hell remarkThe Prime Minister flew into Brussels to beg the bloc’s bosses to overhaul the controversial backstop issue so she can force a deal through ParliamentShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  FEB NewsMr Tusk,unleashed a furious tirade at Brexiteers just seconds after shaking hands with Irish prime minister Leo Varadkar "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May was attempting to smooth over cracks in the UK’s fractured relationship with Brussels today after EU chief Donald Tusk declared there was a “special place in hell” for Brexiteer politicians. The Prime Minister flew into Brussels to beg the bloc’s bosses to overhaul the controversial backstop issue so she can force a deal through Parliament. But Downing Street was downbeat about her chances of success with one No  insider predicting: “We know they’ll say no.”With just  days to go until Brexit Day, negotiations remain deadlocked and frustration in Brussels is mounting.Mr Tusk, President of the European Council, unleashed a furious tirade at Brexiteers who he claimed had convinced the British public to quit without knowing what would follow.   “I have been wondering what that special place in hell looks like for those who promoted Brexit without even a sketch of a plan to carry it out safely,” he said.He also took a swipe at Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn - saying there was “no effective leadership” in the UK that would allow Brexit to be reversed.After making his comments Mr Tusk laughed and nodded as Ireland’s Leo Varadkar told him: “They’ll give you terrible trouble in the British press.” Furious Leave supporting MPs lashed out at the former Polish PM. Andrea Leadsom, the leader of the Commons, said he should apologise for his “spiteful” remarks while Sammy Wilson, the DUP Brexit spokesman, described him as a “devilish Euro maniac”. Mrs May’s official spokesman told reporters: “I think it is a question for Donald Tusk as to whether he considers the use of that kind of language to be helpful.”   No  sees the trip - the first since the PMs deal was resoundingly rejected by MPs - as “part of a process” but it was unclear whether she had any detailed new proposals to put forward. There are three options under consideration - replacing the backstop with “alternative” arrangements, imposing a time limit or a unilateral exit mechanism. The Mirror understands that the PM’s senior Brexit advisor Oliver Robbins has told ministers that a deal can be struck on a time limit to the backstop. In a private document drawn up before Christmas, he wrote: “Our advice is that a unilateral termination mechanism is likely to be rejected in strong terms, and lead to a prolonged hiatus. “A termination clause without a unilateral mechanism may be negotiable, but will need to be relatively simpleit is to be concluded quickly... “If we are pursuing a termination by mutual consent, this will still not be easy, but a discussion with the Irish government and Commission in parallel might be the best way forward.” The proposal is dependent on the Irish PM agreeing to accept a sunset clause. Mrs May will travel to Dublin on Friday evening for dinner with Mr Varadkar.  Ahead of today’s talks, Brussels chief Jean-Claude Juncker said the withdrawal agreement was not open for renegotiation. “She knows that the Commission is not prepared to reopen the issue,” he said. At Westminster, shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry said that Brexit Day should be delayed to give negotiations more time. Cabinet ministers have held secret talks about delaying Brexit Day by two months - but were slapped down by the PM at this week’s Cabinet. Brussels insiders confirmed they may be prepared to offer a “period of grace”the PM’s deal passes to allow extra time to get key legislation through. Ministers came under fire last night after the House of Commons rose more than four hours early despite Brexit uncertainty. Labour’s Diana Johnson said the situation was “bang out of order”. She added: “Considering Brexit is just  days away this is totally irresponsible!”SNP chief whip Patrick Gray said: “Seemingly the Tory Government thinks there’s nothing worth debating or discussing.”The Government has cancelled the February recess for MPs with six key bills to get through before March . One No  insider suggested they would “pull out all the stops” including sitting through the night to get the two essential bits of legislation through in time. There were suggestions that ministers could publish a new employment bill before the next vote on the PM’s deal to win over more Labour MPs. The Mirror revealed last month that Downing Street was offering guarantees on workers’ rights - and it has also hinted at extra funding for Leave-voting Labour areas. Labour MP Lisa Nandy told BBC radio that up to  Labour MPs could be prepared to back a revised deal. Senior Labour insiders suggested the figure could be nearer a dozen. Earlier, Mrs May held crunch talks with Northern Ireland political leaders. Sinn Fein warned that Brexit should trigger an Irish unication referendum which could split the UK. Party leader Mary Lou McDonald said: “If British politicians cannot accept the specic needs of this country, of the north of Ireland,British politics is incapable of acknowledging and upholding the Good Friday Agreement and preventing the hardening of the border, then the only last option – the backstop of last resort – is a referendum on Irish unity.” The warning capped a frustrating morning for the PM with the Northern Irish parties claiming they still had no idea what strategy she would pursue. Colum Eastwood, leader of the nationalist SDLP, claimed there “is no magical solution” for technology to prevent a hard border. “We need to get over all this messing around,” he said. Alliance Party leader Naomi Long said Mrs May failed to set out which of the three options she will pursue with EU chiefs. “I’m tired of people chasing unicorns. It has to stop, we don’t have time,” she added.

title: theres not much going politics
story: NewsTheres not much going on with politics and Brexit so MPs have taken a half dayThe House of Commons rose four hours early today at .pm because there wasnt much to doShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  FEB News"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email MPs took a half day today, because, you know, theres not much going on with Brexit and whatever.Business announced by the Government was thin on the ground for Wednesday, so theCommonsbegan sitting began at .am and ended at .pm. TheCommonsusually runs until .pm on Wednesdays. And with Brexit still  days away, its totally understandable that Ministers chose to take a leisurely approach. Thousands of pages of UK laws need updating to cope with Britains departure from the EU, and theyll need scrutinising by MPs by the end of March. But we guess thats a job for another day.  Labours Diana Johnson said the situation was bang out of order, writing on Twitter : Considering Brexit is just  days away this is totally irresponsible! SNP chief whip Patrick Gray said: Seemingly the Tory Government thinks theres nothing worth debating or discussing.Proceedings began with Cabinet Office questions followed by Prime Ministers Questions. Ten minutes were then used up by the introduction of a backbench bill, before a debate on two social security motions. The adjournment debate focused on prostate cancer and started at .pm rather than pm, as would normally be the case. Elsewhere in Parliament, MPs were involved in afternoon debates in Westminster Hall - their second debating chamber - while proceedings in the House of Lords chamber began at pm and were predicted to run until pm.   The Government last week announced it was cancelling the February recess for MPs, and legislation connected to Brexit still has to be approved. Valerie Vaz, Labours Shadow Commons Leader said: “Theresa Mays zombie Government continues lurching from one crisis to the next. While the Government has been locked in bitter infighting and chaos over their botched Brexit negotiations, the needs of the country have been completely neglected. “This Government has no vision, no new ideas and crucially no legislation to fill the Parliamentary timetable.Best for Britain supporter and Labour MP Virendra Sharma said: “This is not on. Parliament still has tons of legislation to get through before the end of March, including thousands of pages of statutory instruments.   “Brexit is the most important legislative and political process since the Second World War. It makes no sense to go home and avoid working on ensuring the country’s future when there’s so little time left.”Downing Street insisted there was a lot of work going on. The Prime Ministers official spokesman said: The business of the House is set out in advance, there have been days recently where they have been working beyond midnight dealing with statements and with debates on Brexit.   I think this week they have been dealing with some important domestic statutory instruments and other signicant issues which are going to be debated in the coming days. Askedthe situation was embarrassing, the spokesman said: There is a lot of work going on in relation to Brexit. We have not moved the motion to have February recess in order that MPs can have extra time to be dealing with Brexit and other domestic matters.

title: alfie lambs mum sent text
story: NewsAlfie Lambs mum sent text saying they know were lying after car seat deathThe Old Bailey heard a message sent by Adrian Hoare to her boyfriend Stephen Waterson, from Croydon, said: "They know that we are lying"ShareByLuke OReillyEmily Pennink:,  FEB NewsAlfie Lamb was crushed to death in the footwell of a car, the Old Bailey was told "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum whose little boy was allegedly crushed by a car seat messaged her boyfriend saying police know were lying, in the aftermath, jurors were told. Adrian Hoare, , is accused of doing nothing when -year-old Stephen Waterson allegedly squashed three-year-old Alfie Lamb during a trip in his Audi convertible last February. Testying at the Old Bailey, she said she was scared of Waterson - and felt little when he bragged about his important family. Waterson was previously accused in court of using the fact his father is ex-Tory minister Nigel Waterson to make himself untouchable. She said she called her son my little noodle and fatpants. Hoare said: Hewas good with him. They had a bond as well. She said that Waterson also had a nickname for Alfie, calling him Tarzan. Asked about another name used for Alfie and she replied: Little s***.  Katy Thorne, QC, defending Hoare, asked: What about the name little s***  She replied: It was just another name it was not to be nasty or horrible it was just another name. Hoare told the court that both her and Waterson had hit Alfie in the past but only little taps. Waterson told the Old Bailey he lied to police after the incident because he was worried that he would get in trouble because the driver of the car, Marcus Lamb, had been disqualied. He told emergency operators he had been driving by and stopped to help try and revive Alfie.  The couple then claimed Alfie had been injured in a taxi which had driven off. A message sent from Hoare to Waterson just hours after the incident at .pm on February  of last year was read to the jury. It said: They know that we are lying. Duncan Atkinson, prosecuting,said: Even before you had reached the hospital you did not know what lies she had told the police, you were trying to get her alone and away from the police. Waterson answered: No-one was allowed in the room with Alfie, Alfie was with doctors. I did not know what lies she had told the police.  Mr Atkinson said: You were trying to get her alone. Waterson asked him: Is it a crime to be alone with your partner  He added: I have already admitted lying in the beginning, I have pleaded guilty to it, lies were told, I did not want to get anyone in trouble. Waterson is accused of deliberately moving his seat back because he was annoyed at Alfies crying. Giving evidence at the Old Bailey, Hoare said she felt scared when her partner was annoyed or angry, adding: You never knew how he was going to react to things. The hairdresser told jurors how police had been called after an incident in Gravesend, Kent, the year before Alfie died. She said she had been at a friends house when she heard Waterson had been seeing another woman. I asked him over the phone what was going on and we started arguing. He had come down to Gravesend in the car and asked me to go and speak to him. I had gone to speak to him and he had said that to me to get in the car. He started driving stupidly and he was shouting at mehe did not carehe killed us in the car. He was driving at speed and he did not carethere was other cars coming towards him or anything, she said.  Katy Thorne QC, defending, asked: When he said he did not carehe killed us, who was us  Hoare replied: I had just found out I was pregnant at the time. He was saying himself, me and the baby. She went on: I was scared and I eventually got him to stop the car. He then took me back down to near where my friends car was and went back to her house to speak to the police. My friends had been ringing Stephens phone trying to get him to take me back to the house and saying they would ring the policehe didnt.  Ms Thorne asked Hoareshe knew Watersons family had some important jobs. Hoare replied: He used to put it in conversation, yeah. Asked how it made her feel, she said: Little compared to him but I didnt really have anything. Hoare described Alfie as like any normal three-and-a-half-year-old boy. The defendant, who had a troubled upbringing in Gravesend, said: He could be naughty. He would try to climb about. He had a good imagination. Hoare said she used to call Alfie her little noodle and fat pants, while Waterson used the nickname Tarzan.  On February  last year, Alfie was captured on CCTV running around and holding his mothers hand. Hoare said Alfie had been happy on the shopping trip but began getting tired and stroppy. On Watersons relationship with her son, Hoare said: There had been times that Stephen had told him not to do something or he would tell him to be quiet and Alfie would not listen so he had got annoyed with him sometimes. Hoare denied she had hit her son, but said both she and Waterson would tap his hand. She told how she met Waterson in  after she moved to Blackpool for a fresh start. Her previous boyfriend was jailed for setting fire to her house in Gravesend, jurors were told.  Waterson had a big personality and was nice but did not like her speaking to other people, she said. Hoare suspected he had been unfaithful with ious women during their relationship. But she said: When I confronted him with it, he said I was being silly, I was being paranoid. Hoare and Waterson, of Croydon, south London, have denied manslaughter and the trial continues.

title: amber peats family went shopping
story: NewsAmber Peats family went shopping in Tesco and had tea before reporting her missingThe -year-old was found hanged on June , , three days after leaving her home in Mansfield, NottinghamshireShareByRod Malcolm:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAmber Peat, , from Mansfield "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTragic Amber Peat was last seen by a neighbour cleaning his car, an inquest into the death of the -year-old heard today. Adam Lamb said the teen smiled at him and was chewing her sleeve as she walked past him in the street in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, on May , . He had closed a car door to make it easier for her to pass, reports Nottinghamshire Live. She smiled asto say thanks. She was chewing her sleeve and walked along Westfield Lane, he told the inquest. She was looking into the bushes asshe was going inside them and then she was gone. After a TV appeal, Mr Lamb dialled  the next night and passed on details, saying he believed she was aged between nine or .  Chief superintendent Rob Grfin, for Nottinghamshire Police, who is responsible for missing person teams, said police officers spoke to Mr Lamb, but he was among many callers who reported sightings although they did not know her. Unfortunately the officers didnt ask Mr Lamb to take them to the scene and conduct a more thorough search, he said. Mr Lamb was like many others who describes a person who generally fits the bill for Amber rather than I know Amber. The bushes were dense and Mr Grfin said officers would have been forgiventhey had not found her hanged. A pathologist said there was no evidence others were involved in her death.  The inquest was told Ambers mother suspected her of attention seeking on the night she left home. PC Nicola Roe filled in a missing person form while speaking to mother Kelly Peat. She was told Amber had been asked to empty a cool box, was not happy about it and left. Assistant Coroner Laurinda Bower, who is conducting the hearing at the Council House in the city, asked about her observations of Mrs Peat. She seemed matter of fact when she was describing the situation, the officer said. The coroner asked: Did that surprise you  The officer said: Not really, to be honest. She seemed not particularly emotional or upset, maybe frustrated.  She described her background, referred to Amber throwing temper tantrums, what she called attention seeking. Mrs Peat said Amber had gone missing before and ed home safely.The mother seemed well rehearsed in giving information the officer said. PC Roe told the coroner: They expected her back the next morning. The coroner askedshe knew the family went to Tesco and had their tea before alerting the police that Amber was missing. PC Roe answered: I dont remember being told that or discussing specics with them. The inquest heard Ambers case was initially classed as medium risk by Nottinghamshire Police. When she had disappeared before while living in Derbyshire, that force graded them as high given her personal circumstances the coroner said. The inquest continues.

title: couples 2500 holiday ruined 8ft
story: NewsCouple’s £, holiday ruined by ft seaweed mountains on luxury beachLaurel Cormack and David Crook, from Essex, have blasted TUI after claiming their Corfu stay was marred by seaweed mountainsShareCommentsByHelen Le Caplain:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video familys--holiday-ruined-seaweed-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA furious couple have said their pound, dream holiday was ruined - by stinking ft seaweed mountains which meant they couldnt use the beach. Sun lovers Laurel Cormack and David Crook say the luxury five-star resort in Corfu looked like a swamp. They had been looking forward to spending two weeks at TUIs Mayor Verde Grand Resort in Agios Gordios, which has a well-publicised private beach. However when the couple got there they found the usually golden sands littered with towering ft-wide smelly seaweed mounds buzzing with flies. David claims they were only able to spend half a day on the hotel beach and had to abandon their sunbeds due to the seaweed-choked waters and head to the crowded hotel pool.   The recruitment consultant blasted TUIs cavalier attitude to their complaints and for failing to inform guests of the natural phenomenon in advance so they could make alternative plans. TUI said they were sorry to hear of their disappointment and would be in contact with them again. David, from Southend-on-Sea, Essex, said: Were very much beach people and always book hotels with their own piece of beach with them. If were relaxing we prefer to sit on the beach rather than by the pool as it always gets crowded. The black seaweed was in very long strips andyou put your foot in it it would stick to your legs. In the water it was ft deep.   The seaweed was smelly and had a lot of flies around it, the water wasnt clear either. The holiday wasnt as good as it could have been as the one facility we paid for [the beach], the whole reason we picked that hotel, we werent able to take advantage of. When we booked the holiday online I was expecting the golden sands I saw in the brochure, not mounds of stinking seaweed. The -year-old said both he and his customer service assistant we Laurel, , were taunted by glossy promotional videos displayed in the hotel showcasing the resorts unspoiled beaches.  David said: The really irritating thing was in the main reception they had a big -inch TV with a continuous looped video. It kept showing all the bits of the hotel that wed booked the holiday for and werent able to use because they were seaweeded out. They were even playing in the lts and showing the same thing - we couldnt get away from them. Grandad-of-one David said that diggers were out at am scooping up the seaweed from the sand and dumping it in mounds on the hotel area of the beach instead of taking it away. David said: When we complained about it the TUI rep shrugged her shoulders and said theres nothing we can do, the hotel and local authority is doing all they can.  The diggers were there a couple of hours from am on a few mornings trying to clear the beach but as fast as they moved it the seaweed ed. They werent removing it though just piling it up, it was an eyesore. Apparently a couple of weeks before we were there there was a dredger that took away about  tonnes of seaweed. We werent there for that but you dont order a dredger and get diggers on the beachits not a problem. We could have used the less affected public beach further along but that would have entailed paying for sunbeds, parasols and snacks which defeats the object of going all inclusive. Our argument has always been never about assigning blame or responsibility for the seaweed. Its a natural phenomena, its not the hotel or TUIs fault and I never said it was.  What I was really incensed about was the fact that all theyre doing is hiding behind it being a natural phenomena. It first started at the end of March and we went in June - theyd known about this for three months. Do they not monitor their resorts for this type of event  Do they not noty customers  If wed had an informed choice we wouldnt have cancelled our holiday, but we would have just gone to a dferent resort not affected by it. I dont want a load of money back, I just want them to hold their hands up and admit its something they should have made people aware of.  I wouldnt want other people to go through the experience, its just wrong. David complained to TUI in writing and said he was disappointed with their response - even receiving a missive thoughtlessly sent out. David said: I had an email from one TUI rep again explaining it was a natural phenomenon and that she was sorry about the incontinence this has caused. My first thought was that the email hadnt been put through spell check or checked for any autocorrects it was just speedily bashed out with little or no thought. Ive also tried speaking to them on the phone and on one glorious occasion was on hold for  minutes listening to a continuous loop of the same song - by the end of it I was losing the will to live. Dad-of-two David said the experience had put him off booking a TUI holiday in the future. David said: The cavalier attitude TUI took has meant that we will never use them again and nor would we recommend them. The amount we paid might not be a lot of money to a lot of people, but its a big chunk of money for us. Were not wealthy people were just normal working people - its our two weeks of rest and relaxation. TUIs whole attitude really disappointed me, its just left a really bad taste in the mouth. I never said it was their fault, all I was saying was do you not monitor your resorts for this kind of occurrences to let people know so they can make an informed choice about whether they want to proceed with it or not  A TUI spokesman said: Were sorry to hear of the Cormack partys disappointment and we will be in contact the customers directly once again to discuss in further detail.

title: emiliano salas shipwreck hunter solved
story: NewsEmiliano Salas shipwreck hunter has solved some of the worlds greatest maritime mysteriesIn his  year career David Mearns has found  wrecks lost on ocean floors for decades and even centuriesShareByMatt Roper:,  FEB NewsDavid Mearns is the worlds leading shipwreck finder "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email He has been the face of the privately-funded search for the plane was carrying Argentine footballer Emiliano Sala . And within just a few hours David Mearns managed to track down the missing Piper Malibu on Sunday, which was on its way to Cardf when it disappeared last month.Sala’s family appealed to the marine scientist after an official search for the aircraft was stood down and an online crowdfunding campaign to fund it raised more than pound,. But those who know David were not remotely surprised the man known as The Shipwreck Hunter was able to locate the plane so quickly. The expert, who was born in the US but is now a British citizen living in Sussex, has helped solve some of history’s greatest maritime mysteries.   He has lead searches for shipwrecks that have been at the bottom of the sea of decades, even centuries, making  major historical discoveries over the last  years. Using sonar technology and remote-controlled submarines, his expeditions have also set records for finding wrecks at extreme depths - and even helped solve crimes that would have remained forever undetected. But despite his successes he still dreams of finding one wreck which has eluded him - Sir Ernest Shackleton’s Endurance, which crashed into ice and sank off Antartica in .  He told the Times in : “If I could cap it all off with Endurance, I would be a happy, happy man because it is the ultimate shipwreck search in terms of dficulty and challenge.“Harder than Titanic. Finding a deep-water shipwreck in the Weddell Sea when it is covered in ice, you are not going to get any harder than that.” Most of David’s finds, though, have been the result of exceptionally hard work - often years of research, months at sea and millions of pounds. And with three Guinness World Records for underwater discoveries, including one for the deepest shipwreck ever found - the German blockade runner Rio Grande, which was discovered at a depth of ,ft - he is now regarded as the man to turn to when it comes to retrieving from the ocean floor. One of the -year-old’s most famous discoveries was the HMS Hood, one of Britain’s greatest battleships, which was sunk by the German navy’s Bismark in May .  There were just three survivors among the , on board, their lives saved by an air bubble that pushed them back to the surface. Among them was Ted Briggs, who David had met and sought consent from before setting out for a Channel  documentary to find the ship in . He eventually found the wreck at a depth of , ft at the bottom of the Denmark Strait, where he got another Guinness World Record for the deepest live broadcast on the internet, with live footage of the HMS Hood being streamed around the world. But he later recalled how there was none of the usual shouts of excitement when the ship was finally discovered. He said: “There were no whoops or joy of back-slaps. It was such an emotional and sad moment for me. I didn’t feel like celebrating in any way.”  When a plaque was placed on the wreck, now a recognised war grave, he made sure that it was Ted Briggs’ hands in control of an underwater robot when it wasreleased onto the wreck. He remembered: “For Ted personally, it allowed him a chance to say goodbye to his shipmates, to remove from his shoulders the guilt that he had felt his whole le as one of only three who survived. “In a sense, he laid a ghost to rest. It was something that I’ll never ever forget - a very proud moment for everybody that we witnessed that.” Other sunken warships he has found with his company Blue Water Recoveries include the HMAS Sydney, an Australian navy battle cruiser sunk by the Germans off Australias west coast in November , killing . It was the the country’s greatest maritime mystery for  years until he found the ship in . David also found the hospital ship Centaur, which was torpedoed off Queensland by a Japanese submarine in , for which he was awarded an honorary Medal of the Order of Australia.  He was also part of a team in  led by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, which located the wreckage of the Japanese battleship Msashi in the Sibuyan Sea. And in  he found a wreck he believes to be the SS Athenia, the first ship sunk in the Second World War at a cost of  lives when German U-boat commander Fritz Julius Lemp torpedoed the transatlantic liner – believing it was a warship – just hours after Britain had declared war on the Nazis. Describing his care with such wrecks, where many lives were lost, he said: “The sanctity of those grave sites and whoever has been lost is very important. “They are major unmarked grave sites, with no head stones to show who has been lost there, and that why we take this effort andto put plaques on the wreck, to leave a marker that those people haven’t been forgotten.” David, who trained as a marine biologist, began his career as a search and recovery contractor for the US Navy.  But his le changed forever when he was tasked with finding MV Lucona, a cargo ship which was blown up in the Indian Ocean in  at the cost of six lives. After finding the ship at ,ft, he found it had been blown apart by a bomb for an insurance fraud by Austrian businessman Udo Proksch, who was subsequently convicted in  of murdering six of his crew. He went on to defy the odds by finding dozens of other lost vessels, many of which had been shrouded in mystery for decades, boasting a  per cent success rate. Describing the months he often spends at sea searching for wrecks, he says: “Being on the water is great, I love being out there.  You see some days when it’s call, and days when it’s really mountainous seas. You’re working every minute of every hour when you’re awake.” He says that the discovery he’s most proud of was the SMAS Sydney, which nobody thought would ever be found. He said: “It’s not exaggerating to say that all of Australia was following that search. We had the worst luck, everything went wrong. Equipment failures, bad weather, the ship broke down…” He said he felt “pure exhilaration” when it showed up on his sonar.   In March , David announced the discovery of Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gaza’s Esmerelda, which sunk in . It is believed to be the earliest ship from Europe’s Age of Discovery ever to be found and excavated. Despite his extraordinary career, David says he will only be satisfied when when he finds three elusive wrecks. One is the legendary Endurance, but he won’t reveal the other two as shipwreck hunting is a competitive business. He says: “There’s three of them, and I haven’t given up on them. They leave this tortured feeling that you have, of unfinished business.”
