title: letters-remainers-should-not-give-up-and-should-become-returners
story: Lying being not only acceptable but effective, the Brexiters cannot give up their compulsion. For instance consider the Conservative MP Daniel Kawczynskirsquos distortion of the truth regarding our share of Marshall Plan aid .However, much more serious is the fact that Mrs May is either distorting our unwritten constitution or is seeking to ldquorewrite it to meet the needs of her eternally discredited party. She claimed last week that she opposed the Grieve and Cooper amendments on the grounds that they ldquowould allow Parliament to usurp the proper role of the Executive. This is utter nonsense. I understand that ldquo there is any democratic legitimacy in our system, it lies with the democratically elected MPs. As Edmund Burke said ldquoYour representative owes you ... his judgment and he betrays, instead of serving you,he sacrices it to your opinionhellip"How should we Remainers react to the looming catastrophe  I suggest that we do so by refusing to give up and by becoming Returners. As Will Hutton has said, ldquothe British are culturally and philosophically Europeans the consequence being that many of the  million who voted Remain will surely have no intention of giving up that heritage, ever.John Milne, Ardgowan Drive, Uddingston.AS we get closer to the clf edge of a No Deal Brexit, we have to ponder the possible predicament of the UK.Despite the optimistic noises of the May contingent, rather like whistling in the dark, that the EU will relent and offer changes to the Withdrawal Agreement, we could well see ourselves out in the cold from March .It is all rather reminiscent of the Prodigal Son, a story where a young man, guaranteed an inheritance, decided he wanted independence to make his own way in the world.Many of us know how that ended. He squandered his opportunities, fell into hard times and came back chastened to his father who forgave him his errors and welcomed him home.Could the same fate await the UK, which demands sovereignty and striking out on its own I doubt that the EU will be as charitable and forgiving as the father of the prodigal sonwe fall on hard times and come back chastened, seeking our former relationship with the EU.Denis Bruce, Rannoch Gardens, Bishopbriggs.ITS increasingly clear there wont be a second EU referendum, plus, while Article  may be delayed, it wont be revoked. So its Theresa Maysdeal or No Deal ndash thats the most likely binary choice available to our  MPs. Nicola Sturgeon opposes Theresa Mays compromise deal while absolutely insisting no deal is the very worst outcome for Scotland ndash so how are her  SNP MPs going to vote in the Commons  Alongside Jacob Rees-Moggs ardent Brexiters for the probable chaos of No Deal ndash or, albeit reluctantly, for Theresa Mays compromise  Both are politically untenable to the SNP. But is Ms Sturgeon capable of putting aside her Scotland versus the rest of the UK games and puerile party-political point-scoring, to do whats best for the people of Scotland Martin Redfern,Woodcroft Road, Edinburgh.CHRISTOPHER Idesays there are ious reasons people voted Leave but the fact is Brexiters rubbished the benefits of EU membership and called well-informed warnings "Project Fear". Yet our membership was central to the Thatcher sales pitch which led to the opening of Nissanrsquos Sunderland car plant.Even on Sunday, when Nissan itself explained that Brexit was a factor in its decision to build the new SUV in Japan, airtime was still given to Jacob Rees-Mogg to deny this though he has no car industry expertise or experience and his Somerset constituency could hardly be further away from the north-east.As an ordinary minister, Theresa May admitted a great deal of inward investment depended on us being part of the EU. Sadly, as Prime Minister she tried to hide her own Governmentrsquos assessments of the economic damage Brexit would do ndash especially to the north-east of England ndash ploughing on asthe  vote was sacred.Rev Dr John Cameron, Howard Place, St Andrews.AT the weekend I was watching The Italian Joband I was struck by the last scene and how it was very like the current Brexit situation. There you had Michael Caine inching towards the gold bars and the bus precariously balanced on the clf edge, telling his gang of English football supporters to move back to counter balance his weight and telling them that no-one should try to get off the bus. As the balance shts and the gold slides further away to the end of the coach Cane turns to his companions and say "wait a minute lads, Ive got an idea".And the scene shts to the outside and the soundtrack comes up with the theme song We are The Self Preservation Society, whichJacob Rees-Mogg, David Cameron et al had been on the coach is highly appropriate.It found it amusing and quite apposite regarding the position we are in. The fact the characters in the film heist are all English and all the foreign chaps are either evil or incompetent or both sounds like Boris et al speaking about those EU coves trying to do down the crooks. All that was missing was Caine in leopard-print kitten heels and we would be in Brussels.Ronald H Oliver, Woodside Road, Elie.Read more:IM truly at a loss at trying to understand our friends and neighbours, the Irish.One hundred years ago they demanded "their right" to be an independent sovereign nation making its own laws and economic decisions.Is it not somewhat ironical and somewhat galling when Great Britain has voted to take back its right to make its laws and economic decisions again, we now have a situation where the Irish Taoiseach and his unelected EU friends in Brussels are endeavouring to obstruct Britains democratic decision to do so.Ironic, nest pas mes amis Robin Gilmour,Mosspark Avenue, Glasgow.MUCH is being made of the sense of loyalty between Ireland and the EU and now with the United States. However, the loyalty shown by the UK to Ireland in making a pound billion contribution towards helping it during the financial crisis despite the UKs own problems seems to have been quickly forgotten.Paul Lewis, Guardwell Crescent, Edinburgh.Read more: PM must abort Brexit kamikaze mission

title: garment-factory-to-be-home-for-channel-4-in-glasgow
story: Channel  says it is in "advanced negotiations" with Castleforge Partners to lease just over , sq ft in The Garment Factory building, and will use it as its new Creative Hub.The broadcaster plans to lease the space on the first floor of the building, in Montrose Street in the city centre, which has recently undergone a refurbishment.The Garment Factory is a large building in the Merchant City Central Conservation Area.Built in , it was originally the garment factory of J  W Campbell.Channel  intends to take up the space in the building from late .Jonathan Allan, Channel rsquos chief commercial officer said: "Wersquove seen a range of incredibly impressive potential options across the city as a home for our new Creative Hub in Glasgow."However, The Garment Factory stood out as an iconic building which would give us the flexibility of space we need and the proximity to other creative businesses and services in Glasgow city centre.Alistair Urquhart, associate director, CBRE, which is negotiating the deal, said: ldquoThe Garment Factory is a modern and unique building which will provide an ideal fit for Channel ."Having advised Channel  on a series of property related matters we are delighted to be close to securing the first of its regional hubs."Channel  announced in October that Glasgow would be the location of one of its new Creative Hubs, alongside another in Bristol, with Leeds named as a new National HQ.

title: loch-lomond-hires-40000-litter-manager
story: But for decades Loch Lomond has been blighted by anti-social campers and daytrippers who leave litter and refuse in their wake, despoiling the areas natural beauty.Now bosses at the he Loch Lomond  The Trossachs National Park Authority are to open a new front in the war against waste by employing a dedicated Litter Prevention Manager to try to solve the problem.Previous attempts to curb environmental damage such as plastic rubbish, abandoned camping gear and discarded tin cans on the Lochs shores have seen campers herded into dedicated zones, police monitoring laybys and endless information campaigns.But campaigners say that the latest attempt of employing someone to keep a lid on the problem shows that the fight against litter louts is being lost.The park has been hindered by the fact that much of its  square miles is covered by dferent councils who dont have the same litter collecting strategies.:Ten campers reported for breaching new national park lawsFly-tipping is also a huge problem, with burnt out cars, abandoned tyres and other detritus affecting laybys and verges.The job of the Litter Prevention Manager, a post which pays between pound, and pound,, will see the creation of a "joined-up" strategy to deal with rubbish being dumped in the park, a top priorities in the authoritys -Year Plan.Nick Kempe, a member of the executive committee of the Scottish Campaign for National Parks, who also runs the blog Parkswatch Scotland, said he welcomed the appointment but had several reservations.He said: "I think the reason they have employed such a well-paid person is that they are meant to be working together in partnership with local authorities and they have failed to do so for several years."One of the problems is that although they have councillors for the local authorities on their board, they seem to be incapable of getting staff to cooperate."You might raise eyebrows about it being a senior management post, but I suspect what they are attempting to do is try to give some leadership across the local authorities that make up the area."Mr Kempe said one of the main problems was that dferent councils had dferent policies, with some not keen on putting bins in laybys.:Police to tackle long-staying layby layabouts at Loch Lomond#"Whats basically happened under austerity is that no-one wants to spend any more money so they all try and leave it to others to clear up the mess. There is quite a big issue around that, and also over flytipping," Mr Kempe said."This is a much wider urban problem. Litter in the countryside is a big issue."A post is not going to do this on its own - it needs political support to make everybody work together and create a workable strategy."The National Park attracts more than four million visitors every year and has some of Scotlands busiest major roads passing through it.In  the Park Authority banned wild camping in a bid to restrict overnight visitors to designated campsites. The scheme was being brought in amid concerns over the impact unrestricted camping, including the amount of rubbish which had been strewn around the Loch.But efforts to cut out rubbish have been in vain, with many areas still marred by trash. Dave Morris, a former Director of Ramblers Scotland, said the national park authority had wrongly focused on campers as the cause of the scourge, and believes it is day trippers and those driving through who cause much of the problem."Goodness knows whether the appointment of a Litter Manager on a salary of around pound, pa is going to make any dference," Mr Morris said."In its -plus years of existence this national park has demonstrated that it hasnt a clue about how to deal with litter and is more interested in spending its resources on the persecution of innocent campers than dealing with the real culprits."However, a spokesperson from Loch Lomond  The Trossachs National Park Authority said: "The national park is one of the most beautul places in Scotland but unfortunately litter can be a problem blighting some parts of this outstanding landscape, especially during peak periods.:Plans to ban wild camping from parts of Loch Lomond given green flag#"Addressing this issue is one of our key priorities and we have recently appointed a Litter Prevention Manager who will be responsible for developing a National Park-wide litter prevention strategy, working with partners to drive positive change."Although the National Park Authority is not responsible for collecting much of the litter left in the national park, we are leading a joined-up approach to tackle this issue together."Our new Litter Prevention Manager will play a vital role in helping to work collaboratively with stakeholders throughout the national park to prevent litter spoiling the natural beauty of the area."

title: herald-diary-life-is-full-of-ups-and-down-for-sir-chris-bonington
story: GROWING old, continued. Reader Jack Phillipson from Neilston was discussing Brexit with a friend in a noisy cafe and tells us: "My friend says, What about they Spanish matadors  Theyll need to come round soon or they will lose their market. I was vaguely agreeing but eventually felt I had to say that I didnt understand what matadors had to do with it. Matadors  he replied. Im talking about tomata growers."Get the pipOUR picture of unrecognisable hospital food reminded David Knight: "When I was a junior doctor I experienced much trauma in regard to hospital food ndash mostly finding the canteen shut after I got out of theatre. But the one that stands out happened to me when I was myself a patient. After an accident breaking my thumb, I awoke back in the ward to find the affected limb in plaster and suspended from a drip stand. The other arm was strapped to a board and had an intravenous line running. I was literally handless. The kindly ward orderly told me Id missed dinner but she would find me some dessert. Falling back asleep, I next opened my eyes to a plate on my bed table holding an unpeeled orange. Its the thought that counts."Bowled overAND Catriona Kellock in Alva admits: "As a young student nurse in Edinburgh, many years ago, I was given the job of handing out the meals. One gentleman had not ordered pudding and askedthere was a spare one on another tray. He had seen his neighbour with semolina, his favourite. I found a bowl on another tray and gave it to him. When I came to clear up, he hadnt finished it, saying sheepishly, I really prefer the sweet kind of semolina. I looked at the bowl and realised I had given him boiled potatoes in white sauce. They looked very similar."GetawayTHE SNP is being attacked for giving local authorities powers to levy a tax on workplace parking spaces. It reminds us of the health and safety official at a large Glasgow factory giving a talk and asking staff: "Does anyone know the speed limit in the factory car park " A voice replied: "Depends. Do you mean coming in to work or leaving "Rise and shineSAD to hear of the death of former Radio Clyde breakfast host Mike Riddoch, one of the most clever DJs around, although he hated being in the spotlight himself. He once told an old chum of ours that he didnt like to sound too bright and breezy in the morning as it put folk offthey had just woken up. He added: "The greatest compliment Ive ever had is from someone who once said he liked me because however rough I feel, Mike Riddoch seems to be feeling rougher. Had a skinfulEND of an era, as permission is being sought to bulldoze the O ABC music venue on Sauchiehall Street after the recent fire. More student flats no doubt. We remember when Australian singer Jordie Lane, appearing at Celtic Connections, arrived there to hear a fellow act, and was stopped by a bouncer because he was carrying a banana and was told he couldnt take food in. On a whim he askedhe could check it in at the cloakroom and was told he could. At the end of the show he went back to the cloakroom, and when asked what colour his coat was, he replied "Yellow." The girl knew exactly what he wanted and handed him back his banana.TrumpedUS President Donald Trump has been criticised for giving a lacklustre State of the Union address. As John Rain explains: "Once you pretend that Trump has been kidnapped and is doing ransom videos, his speeches are OK to sit through. You just have to pretend that the, I am being treated well has been edited out."Rocky pathJIM from Shawlands reads the interview with mountaineer Sir Chris Bonington in The Herald this week and comments: "Sir Chris said he had ups and downs in his career. Would he not have learned that this pretty much described the whole job on Day One of mountain climbing school "THOSE WERE THE DAYS - : The striking design of the newest church in Glasgow

title: todays-news-the-bbcs-inquisitor-in-chief-john-humphrys-to-step-down
story: The veteran broadcaster, said one front page, was to step down after more than three decades presenting the BBCrsquos flagship radio news programme, Radio rsquos Today.Mr Humphrys, surely aware his show had been scooped on its own star, did eventually crack a joke. ldquoI canrsquot believe you are leaving! a guest told him on air.ldquoAll these stories got up by the press, he replied. ldquoCanrsquot believe a word you read!"Our listeners will miss him and so will I." Gwyneth Williams, Controller of @BBCRadio on the news that John Humphrys is to leave #RToday. pic vZciuRqfMr Humphrys, , told the Daily Mail he had not yet handed in his notice but planned to do so.ldquoIrsquom assuming itrsquoll be this year. Thatrsquos what Irsquom assuming, but I havenrsquot fixed a date, he said of leaving.ldquoItrsquos not easy to leave a job yoursquove been doing for  years. Itrsquos more than half my professional le.ldquoItrsquos not like Irsquom an ambitious youngster with many, many more challenges ahead of me or something like that.ldquoIrsquove always taken the view - and this is the problem in a way - that I would carry on doing it either until they threw me out or had enough of me, or that Irsquod got bored of it or stopped enjoying it.ldquoNone of those things has happened.The BBC, caught on the hop, had no instant response to the story of Mr Humphrysrsquo departure appeared in the press.Only at lunchtime, on Todayrsquos rival, the World at One, did the presenter tell all to his own employers. And he did so to Sarah Montague, his onetime morning co-host.ldquoI genuinely worry about what it is going to be like not doing the Today programme -  years is a very long time, he told her. ldquoI have always enjoyed it, always loved it. And I still do, thatrsquos the problem I should have gone years ago, obviously I should have gone years ago, but I love doing the programme.Gently goaded, he added that he felt he had a relationship with a ldquohuge number of people ...with millions of listeners. That is a huge privilege..Some, however, he admitted, hated his guts. Criticism of Mr Humprhys has mounted over recent years. Many Remainers felt the -year-old did not do enough to interrogate those behind Brexit.The presenter himself - whose decades in the studio came after a meteoric rise from cub reporter, the first on the scene of the Aberfan disaster, to BBC Washington correspondent - has reflected on institutional bias at the Corporation.ldquoWe werenrsquot sufficiently sceptical ndash thatrsquos the most accurate phrase ndash of the pro-European case. We bought into the European ideal, the Today programme interviewer told the Radio Times in ldquoWe didnrsquot look at the potential negatives with sufficient rigour hellip I think wersquore out of that now. I think we have changed.Changed too much, thinks Glasgow-based journalist Peter Geoghegan. ldquoMr Humphrys will rightly be remembered for his pugnacious interviewing of political leaders but recent months have shown the limit of this approach when it comes to tackling complex issues, such as Brexit, ldquo he said.ldquoToo often in recent months, the Today programme has been found wanting on detail and rigour, and Humphrys in particular has repeated erroneous tropes with delving into the detail. Hopefully the time has come for a little less heat and a little more light.Niggles over Brexit did not, however, colour his entire career. ldquoOur listeners will miss him and so will I. Gwyneth Williams, the controller of Radio , said.Mr Humphrys joined Today in  and his departure could trigger a shake-up on the show.Recently Martha Kearney joined the programme, swapping jobs with Sarah Montague, who moved to World At One. Mr Humphrys has railed against the absence of older women on TV. But he is more than aware that his replacement is likely to be female, given the mail dominance of Today.ldquoWe should have another woman on Today, he said back in . ldquoBut then your next question has got to be, so who has to leave ldquoI have no doubt that when I finally keel over or they decide I should be keeled over, a woman will take over from me.In , Mr Humphrys was at the centre of the debate surrounding the gender pay gap at the BBC. His pay was slashed from around pound,-pound, to around pound,-pound,.He said it was his decision to take the cut, telling the Press Association he would ldquolike to think he has given the BBC ldquoreasonable value for money over the years and ldquoIrsquom not exactly on the breadline.Despite his famous grillings and - his critics say - arrogance, Mr Humphrys, who left school at , has suffered from imposter syndrome. Remembering his career, he once said: ldquoI always felt like a bit of a fraud.

title: scottish-government-has-squandered-union-dividend-claims-david-lidington-pms-deputy
story: The Cabinet Office Minister made his remarks during Prime Ministerrsquos Questions after clashing with the SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford.The Highland MP had launched an attack on the UK Government over pensions, complaining how it had "sneaked through a cut in pensions credit which will see some couples up to pound, a year worse off".Mr Blackford went on: "An estimated , more pensioners are now living in poverty than in . Does the minister agree that his Government needs to change course and instead of robbing pensioners start supporting them "But Mr Lidington ndash standing in for Mrs May, who was in Belfast holding Brexit talks with the local parties - replied: "What this House voted for some years ago is perfectly logical and in line with the intention of the benefit system."The Nationalist leader insisted the Government was continuing to put its ldquohands into the pockets of the poorest in our society". Pensioner poverty, he argued, was "not a myth, it is a reality" as he called for pension reform to be taken by the Scottish Government in an independent Scotland.However, Mr Lidington pointed out ndash to SNP MPs gesticulating with anger ndash how it was in the power of the Scottish Government under the devolution legislation to ldquotop up social security benefitthey chose to do so.He argued last weekrsquos Scottish Government Budget had "led to Scots being more highly-taxed than people in any other part of the UK".The Cabinet Office Minister added: "The SNP has squandered that Union idend. The message we get from them isyou have an SNP government, Scottish people pay more and get less."Later, after further clashes in Points of Order, Mr Blackford declared: ldquoThere is no Union idend. He stressed how the Scottish Government had had a pound billion cut to its Budget over the last nine years.When it was pointed out how ahead of the Scottish Budget, Edinburgh received a pound million windfall thanks to consequentials under the Barnett Formula, the SNP leader referred to it as an ldquoequalisation payment, which was not the same as a Union idend.During a session of Holyroodrsquos Finance Committee, Murdo Fraser, the Conservative MSP, accused Derek Mackay, the Scottish Finance Secretary, of being ldquoessentially dishonest about his Budget, which was passed after a deal between the SNP Government and the Greens.The agreement included an allocation of poundm to local government funded by the additional poundm from Whitehall in Barnett consequentials.But Mr Mackay insisted he had been transparent throughout the process.

title: letters-the-younger-generation-deserve-better-than-brexit
story: Like John Milne , I value my European identity immensely and appreciate the fact that the SNP continues to stand up for Scotlandrsquos choice to reject the xenophobic, isolationist option chosen by those misguided souls south of the Border. I can reassure Mr Milne that I have no intention of giving up my desire for continued membership of the EU. I happen to believe that our broad-minded and geographically unrestricted younger generation deserve a better future than the one currently bequeathed to them by those who seem unable to extract themselves from an imperial past.If it does come to leaving, I suspect that it wonrsquot be long until the cynically-misled, exploited Leave voters will turn on those who led the Leave campaign and rejoin the rest of us in order to be, once again, at the heart of European decision-making.Dave Stewart, Blairatholl Avenue, Glasgow.MARTIN Redfern asksNicola Sturgeon is capable of doing ldquowhatrsquos best for the people of Scotland. That is exactly what she is doing. For the last two years she has put Scotlandrsquos constitutional issues to the side and pushed for Scotland and the UK to remain within the customs union and single market. All and any analysis I have read has given that outcome as being in the best economic interests of the UK and Scotland, but Ms Sturgeon, the Scottish Government and Scotlandrsquos Parliament have all been dismissed with contempt.The May Government is only interested in the Tory party and the DUP. The EU has proved extremely flexible in dealing with Mmember territories in or out of the EU, so it was possible Scotland and Northern Ireland could have had a dferent status to England Wales but was never asked. Indeed it has been reported that London insisted to the EU that Scotland be denied sharing in any dferentiation on offer to others.Mr Redfern advocates for what he calls the ldquoMay compromise: trouble is that Theresa May changes the parameters of her deal on a daily basis. Donrsquot believe me ndash ask her own Tory MPs. It is the Tories who have led us to this clf edge, and it will be the Tories who tip us into the abyss. Scotland voted to stay in the EU but has zero status or leverage within the UK ldquoUnion. Ireland is respected and her interests are being protected in the EU Union. The dference is stark and should be an example to any Scot with an ounce of gumption.GR Weir, Mill Street, Ochiltree.ROBIN Gilmourdraws a somewhat simplistic comparison between Irelands long struggle for freedom from British rule and the UKs vote to leave the European Union.He is correct to state that the Republic of Ireland, over hundreds of years, fought against domination by Britain and eventually won its independence. However, Britains partition of Ireland, designed to keep the bulk of the Unionist population and heavy industry under the UK flag, sowed the seeds for future conflict in the north of Ireland.Our present vexatious issue with the Irish protocol has only arisen because the UKs decision to depart from the EU leaves Northern Ireland as, obviously, thanks to the partition of , the only part of the UK that shares a border with an EU country.The Irish Government and the EU are trying to work together with Theresa May and her Government to avoid future loss of le and conflict in Northern Ireland by ensuring that there is no hard border, now, and in the future.The only obstruction to Britain arriving at a solution at present appears to be from those who see the people on the island of Ireland as an irrelevance and a hindrance to a clean break with Brussels,despite  per cent of people in Northern Ireland voting to remain.Mr Gilmours exasperation displays an age-old condescending British attitude towards the Irish that I had hoped had evaporated into the mists of history. As he himself says, Ireland is an independent sovereign nation on a par with Britain. As such, it must be accorded equal importance and respect.Owen Kelly, Dunvegan Drive, Stirling.Read more: Donald Tusk: Theres a special place in hell for people who promoted Brexit

title: posting parcels to eu countries after brexit
story: Q: I have an online business with  per cent international sales, but neither Royal Mail nor the Post Office can sayCN customs labels are going to be required for the EEA EU.Any idea A CN is a customs document, used when goods are being transported overseas. It contains a description and value of the item being posted along with the country of origin. It is valid for items up to £, while a CN label is the same, but for goods worth £ and over.Electronic customs data needs to be supplied whenever a parcel is required to go through Customs clearance. Currently this is applicable to only countries outside of the EU.However, Royal Mails official advice to customers is that they DO prepare to send data to all countries following Brexit.Readers questions: Will I need a new passport after Brexit As you will know, at the minute theres no need for customs declarations or clearance on anything you post to EU destinations. If we leave with a withdrawal agreement it is likely that nothing will change, at least during the transition period until .Butthere is a no-deal Brexit then the current guidance from HMRC is that the same rules will apply to UK businesses exporting to the EU as do to non-EU countries from March .This means that your goods will require a CN or CN form.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.milngavieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The CE safety symbol belongs to the EU"  UK plans new safety certicate mark for when we leave EU viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "MILN | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "MILN | Article Teaser"

months, following a fire in the old building back in .Temporary accommodation on site was made for the nursery children.The new library space at Kinellar SchoolThe new school is built on the same site as its predecessor. As part of the build, the project team used the opportunity to improve facilities in the village by redeveloping a derelict tennis court and constructing an enclosed children’s play park as well as additional parking for use by the school and local community.The school’s social staircase is already becoming a well-used architectural feature alongside its many other bright and airy flexible learning spaces, including the glass fronted library and learning area upstairs.Its teaching wings benefit from cleverly designed acoustics, modern set up and technology offerings in all  classrooms, and are on two levels, with lightwells connecting them.Specially commissioned artwork is also an important feature of the new school.Local artists worked with pupils to design and create a number of pieces, including a large Oak tree in the dining area symbolizing growth with leaves painted by every child.  Aberdeenshire Provost Bill Howatson said: “A great team effort has led to the delivery of an extremely high quality building on time and on budget, and we’re thankful to everyone who has played their part in that. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Erasums students question what will happen after Brexit"  What is the future for Erasmus students after Brexit  viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"“It stands testament to what a community can achieve by working together, right from those dark early days after the fire when local people rallied round to offer soup and sandwiches to staff, to the lovely reception pupils received from the community in Kintore.”Chair of Education and Children’s Services Committee, Councillor Gillian Owen said: “It’s not only wonderful to see the pupils at Kinellar enjoying their new school but also to reflect on what a fantastic learning experience this project has given them. In addition to the educational opportunities – working with artists, the community and the construction team – the pupils have also learned important lessons when it comes to being resilient and flexible.”Head Teacher Pamela Farquhar added: “As much as we loved our time at Kintore it is nice to be back home.“The new school was made possible thanks to Anne Gibson who sold her land to Aberdeenshire Council.“Her husband was a former head teacher here so the school has a special place in her heart.”

title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse impact on the amenities of the properties immediately opposite the site and the surrounding area by reason of overlooking and having a visually overbearing impact.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: what is the future for erasmus students after brexit
story: Irsquom supposed to be here until the end of May. However,the UK parliament canrsquot negotiate with the EU, what is going to happen  Will I have to leave A. The message is clear: you are our friends, our neighbours, our colleagues, and we want you to stay.EU citizens and their family members who are resident in the UK by March  will be able to stay and carry on with their lives in the same way they are now. They will be able to work, study, and access benefits and services in the UK on the same basis after we exit the EU as they do now.So, regardless of a deal or no deal, you will be allowed to study in Scotland - or other parts of the UK - for the rest of the semester.Read more: UK plans new safety certicate mark for when we leave EUWith regards to Erasmus+ funding, the UK will remain in the programme until at least a deal is agreed. title: wine drinkers could be seeing red over brexit price rises
story: The Journal of Wine Economics featured an industry study that says that the amount customers pay could increase by up to  per cent by  in the event of a hard Brexit, or  per cent in terms of a softer Brexit.British vineyards could benefit however.According to a report by WSTA, the Wine and Spirit Trade Association,  percent of wine drunk in the UK is imported. Of this half is produced in the EU, while the remainder comes from Australia, USA, Chile, Argentina, South Africa and New Zealand. There are concerns thatthe right measures are not put in place it could stop imports from crossing the border, which has lead some retailers to stock up on bottles in advance.The WSTA has been advising members for more than a year that they should increase their stock by  per cent as a starting point in case of a no deal Brexit.Miles Beale, chief executive of the Wine and Spirit Trade Association, said: ldquoSince the Referendum, the WSTA has campaigned consistently for a deal with the EU that delivers frictionless trade in goods, with no additional tarfs or costs.ldquoIf the UK ends up with a no-deal Brexit then wine businesses will have to cope with additional tarfs as well as another duty rise - which is highly likely to end up full square in the consumerrsquos lap, bumping up wine prices to an all-time high.ldquoCurrently there are no tarfs on wines from the EU, Chile and South Africa. A no deal Brexit would result in the introduction of tarfs, estimated to cost UK wine importing businesses over £ million a year.ldquoThe introduction of no deal Brexit tarfs would be a double blow for wine businesses after the Chancellor elected to single out wine for a duty rise at the Autumn Budget.From February  the duty on a bottle of wine went up by p, but add a tarf to the duty rise and VAT and this means an average priced bottle of wine, which today costs £., will cost £. in the event of no deal.Read more: How will Brexit affect your travel plans  This is an extra p a bottle more than consumers paid before the referendum result when an average priced bottle of wine was £..There could be some positive benefits for British vineyards however.It is believed that British wines will seem less expensive than its European counterparts as retailers wonrsquot be forced to hike prices because of rate or tarfs.However, British vineyards could be hit with the lack of skilled workers from the EU and vital agricultural funding streams. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: This weeks Caithness Courier
story: Due to circumstances beyond our control, this weekrsquos edition of the Caithness Courier wonrsquot be in the shops until Thursday morning. We apologise for any inconvenience but this was due to a combination of problems with our contract printers and distribution partners.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Thursday  Feb  : AM

story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. There are also fireplaces in two of the bedrooms. Many of the original features have been retained in the property. Viewing is highly recommended to appreciate the true character of Westermill.The property is ideally located on a quiet road close to both the Papdale Primary and Kirkwall Grammar School and it is only a few minutes walk down to the centre of town. To the front of the property is the picturesque Willowburn, as well as additional parking.The living room has a hardwood floor, picture rail and cornice, as does the dining room. There is an archway leading from the dining room to the modern fitted kitchen with  ring hob, double oven, cooker hood, fridge and dishwasher.The ground floor also houses the utility room with plumbing for a washing machine and space for tumble dryer and fridge  freezer. There is a small toilet off the utility room. One of the bedrooms is situated on the ground floor, but could be used as a living room or office space.In the centre of the property is a beautul staircase leading up to a large stained glass feature window and then on to the landing. Off the landing there are a further three double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite shower room. The main shower room is also located on the first floor of the property.There is a large loft space which is partially floored and could potentially be converted into a further one or two rooms, with ample space on the landing for a staircase.There is a walled garden to the front of the property, bordered with bushes and shrubs. story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. When the planning application is submitted, an opportunity will be given for representations to be made to the Planning Authority.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Check your cold weather payment eligibility says Ross MP as temperature plummets
story: Local MP Ian Blackford sayspeople in the Ross, Skye and Lochaber constituency he serves should check eligibility with their nearest Job Centre Plus.This follows an alert of a triggering of the payment for postcode areas IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, between the period    to   .Cold weather payments are made from the Social Fund to certain recipients of Income Support, income-based Jobseekerrsquos Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Universal Credit or Pension Credit during periods of very cold weather.To ldquotrigger the payments, the average temperature at a specied weather station must be recorded as, or forecast to be, degC or below for seven consecutive days.The scheme runs from November  to March  each year.The payment is a fixed amount for each week of cold weather. For many years this was set at pound. a week but the LabourGovernment increased the rate to pound a week as a temporary measure for winters - and -. In , the Coalition Government made the pound rate permanent.Payments should be made automatically to those entitled to them there should be no need to make a claim.However concerns have previously been raised that payments can be missed and Mr Blackford believes it is important that people, who believe that they may be eligible follow this through, particularly as the cold weather bites.He said: ldquoWe have been experiencing quite a prolonged period of cold and wet weather in the Highlands and Islands. It is hugely important that anyone eligible for a cold weather payment receives it. It can really make a dference to a vulnerable person or family who is experiencing high heating costs.ldquoThese payments should be made to eligible iniduals automatically, however, in my experience that is not always the case. I would urge anyone who believes that they may be due a payment to contact their nearest Job Centre Plus and get what they are owed.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross Post Offices affected by shops move
story: SHOP closures in two Easter Ross towns could leave the Post Office seeking new premises from which to operate.The changes affect Invergordon and Tain.A Post Office spokesperson said: ldquoWe are aware that our partner CJ Lang who runs Invergordon Post Office, has given us notice and the store will be closing later this year.ldquoThe branch was run independently and while we always work hard to maintain Post Office services, from time to time, branches do temporarily close. When this happens, we always look to restore services as quickly as possible, as we know how important Post Offices are to communities.ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community.The spokesman also confirmed that in Tain its partner McCollrsquos Retail Group, which runs the Post Office, has also given notice ldquoand the store will be closing in the spring.He said that branch is also run independently and efforts will be made to restore services as quickly as possible.He said: ldquoWe have had interest from some local retailers who are interested in running this branch but it is very early stages so we are unable to comment further at the moment. ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community ndash including banking services like cash withdrawals from high street bank account, bill payments, and of course a wide range of postal services.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
